alert.note: Alert for Santa Barbara County Interior Mountains; Santa Barbara County Southeastern Coast; Santa Barbara County Southwestern Coast; Santa Ynez Mountains Eastern Range; Santa Ynez Mountains Western Range (California) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Fire Weather Watch issued September 25 at 1:59PM PDT until September 28 at 5:00AM PDT by NWS Oxnard
info.description: ...FIRE WEATHER WATCH FROM 5PM TUESDAY THROUGH 5AM THURSDAY FOR WIND AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR THE SANTA YNEZ RANGE AND SURROUNDING FOOTHILLS AND MOUNTAINS... .A combination of moderately strong northerly pressure gradients, weak cold advection, and increasing winds aloft will contribute to the first Fire Weather Watch of the season over the Santa Ynez Mountain Range. A cold storm system in the Pacific Northwest will bring the adequate ingredients for a potential red flag event Tuesday evening through Wednesday night. Sundowners will begin tonight, but increase and expand from the west to the east Tuesday evening. Warm and dry conditions will occur in the foothills just above Santa Barbara and Montecito both Tuesday and Wednesday evenings with temperatures from 75 to 85 degrees and humidity lowering to 15 to 25 percent. Gusty north winds of 50 to 60 mph or possibly higher could lead to rapid fire spread in the foothill areas. This part of Santa Barbara County is particularly vulnerable to fires due to dry fuel moisture values at this time of the year. Stay alert for a potential upgrade to a Red Flag Warning in later forecasts. ...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM TUESDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH LATE WEDNESDAY NIGHT FOR WIND AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR THE SANTA YNEZ RANGE AND SURROUNDING FOOTHILLS AND MOUNTAINS IN SANTA BARBARA COUNTY... The National Weather Service in Los Angeles/Oxnard has issued a Fire Weather Watch FOR WIND AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY, which is in effect from Tuesday afternoon through late Wednesday night. * Winds...North 25 to 35 mph with gusts of 50 to 60 mph, strongest after dark each evening. Isolated gusts to 70 mph possible in the foothills above Montecito. * Relative Humidity...15 to 25 percent, especially during windier periods. * Impacts...If fire ignition occurs there could be rapid spread of wildfire that would lead to a threat to life and property.
info.instruction: A Fire Weather Watch means that critical fire weather conditions are likely to occur in the coming days. Residents near wildland interfaces should prepare now on what to do if a wildfire breaks out. See readyforwildfire.org and wildfirerisk.org for information..
